input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: the moment;italy;the romans;likely tyranny;people;other empires;countrymen;the fold;a ticket;the eu;an army;italian;hungarian soldiers;a strategy;less popular;popular;germany;france;french soldiers;hungary;an eu army;line;german soldiers<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : The EU need its own independent armed forces
output: The EU isn't exactly popular at the moment. They are probably going to get less popular. If they have an army, they may start using French soldiers or German soldiers to keep Hungary and Italy in the fold and Italian and Hungarian soldiers to keep Germany and France in line. This was a strategy the Romans and other empires used because people are willing to kill those who are not their countrymen. An EU army is a ticket to likely tyranny.

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: eu member states;a eu military;legitimacy;un security council authorisation;armed forces;the primary benefit;any subset;the primary advantage;a military;a level;individual national states;the authority;such states;conducted under the authority;the eu member states;military operations;coalitions;the un security council;the eu;eu institutions<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : The EU need its own independent armed forces
output: I wonder what you think the primary benefit of a military under the authority of EU institutions would be. It strikes me that the EU is already able to deploy its armed forces without UN Security Council authorisation - - the EU member states, or any subset of EU member states, can decide to do so. Do you think the primary advantage of a EU military is that military operations conducted under the authority of EU institutions would have a level of legitimacy that neither individual national states ( or coalitions of such states ) or the UN security council could provide? If so, can you say more about why you think that?

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: people;the detriments;raising the minimum wage;would remove these controversies;arguments;a universal basic income;raised prices;goods;appropriate level;involves labor;higher minimum wage;the mean time;an unintended;the population;addressed with universal basic income;raising the price;universal basic income;minimum wage;a large portion;jobs;arguments;a government liability;consequence;a livable age;benefits<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : We shouldn't raise the minimum wage to $ 15 an hour or something similar.
output: Arguments for raising the minimum wage seem to me to actually be arguments for a universal basic income. People's need for a livable age should be addressed with universal basic income. This would remove these controversies regarding appropriate level of minimum wage. Universal basic income is a government liability, which we privatize by raising the minimum wage instead. This would also have an unintended ( perhaps intended ) consequence of raising the price of everything that involves labor to manufacture and distribute. In the mean time, there is a large portion of the population who don't have jobs and thus don't see benefits of higher minimum wage, but do see the detriments of raised prices of goods.

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: create inflation;this new market;whats;a raise;the yacht buyer;made by minimum wage workers;the interest;afford a yacht;would raise prices;a lot;a sudden;build a yacht;businesses;this new economy;buys at the grocery store;the point;turn a profit;paying a poor minimum wage apple picker;buy a yacht;providing goods;minimum wage consumers;the cost;the minimum wage;wages;inflation;savings;the apples;worth;services;a grim scenario;fire everyone;the goods;the workers;cost;last week<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : We shouldn't raise the minimum wage to $ 15 an hour or something similar.
output: Businesses wouldn't just give up and fire everyone because they can no longer turn a profit, they would raise prices. Now you say what's the point then, won't that just create inflation? Whats the value in paying a poor minimum wage apple picker more if you then have to go around and charge him more for the apples he buys at the grocery store? Now his savings from his wages from last week are worth relatively less since cost of all the goods and services have increased but the interest on his savings hasn't gone up. This looks like a grim scenario. But now consider the yacht buyer who is looking to buy a yacht made by minimum wage workers and when the minimum wage was raised all of a sudden the cost to build a yacht increased, inflation made his savings worth a lot less and he didn't get a raise. He might not be able to afford a yacht now in this new economy and the workers that would have made it will now be providing goods and services to this new market of minimum wage consumers.

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: people;a bad thing;living wages;that money;give the place;increasing the wages;education;will decrease the profits;the people;transportation;disgraceful;cases;the businesses;food;wealthy owners;basic life;the ceo;make lot;make that money;more full time jobs;clothes;housing;workers;the cost;businesses;afford basic things;the company;minimum wages;the top 1 %<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : We shouldn't raise the minimum wage to $ 15 an hour or something similar.
output: People need to live. They need to be able to afford basic things like food, housing, education, transportation and clothes. Currently, that isn't possible with most minimum wages in the US. It's disgraceful that businesses are allowed to let workers have one or more full time jobs without paying them enough to live a very basic life. Increasing the wages will decrease the profits of the company. But who does that hurt? In most cases it's the really wealthy owners, the CEO's and others in the top 1 %. Is that really a bad thing? I'm not saying that they shouldn't be allowed to make lot of money, but do you really believe that they should be able to make that money at the cost of the people they employ? If the businesses aren't able to survive while paying living wages to their workers, maybe they shoud give the place to someone that can?

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: crime;wong kim ark;aliens;worthy;punishment;unsettled;inherent;civil;the country;the chinese exclusion act;1964;the land;non - arbitrary deprivations;citizenship;owes allegiance;contemplated the permissibility;5th cir;justice brewer;united states;deprived of the right;banishment;the concept;own terms;the law;congress;the citizen;banishment;the supreme court;fong yue ting;set foot;stipulations;ratified the iccpr;exclude citizens;international law;the other hand;some justices;own country;the international covenant;394;pertinent;political rights;admit that possibility;answer the question;soil;the question;dissent;a punishment;absent<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : The US gov. could remove legal resident status from citizens.
output: I think the question is unsettled. But see Worthy v. United States, 328 F. 2d 386, 394 ( 5th Cir. 1964 ) ( “We think it is inherent in the concept of citizenship that the citizen, when absent from the country to which he owes allegiance, has a right to return, again to set foot on its soil. ” ). On the other hand, some justices of the Supreme Court have contemplated the permissibility of banishment as a punishment for crime. See, e. g., Justice Brewer’s dissent in Fong Yue Ting ( “Banishment may be resorted to as punishment for crime” ). International law seems to admit that possibility too : Art. 12 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights declares that “no one shall be arbitrarily deprived of the right to enter his own country, ” but non - arbitrary deprivations of that right are implicitly entertained. The U. S. has ratified the ICCPR so its stipulations are the law of the land, albeit non - self - executing. And I don’t think Wong Kim Ark is pertinent. The Chinese Exclusion Act by its own terms excluded only aliens, not citizens, and doesn’t answer the question of whether Congress may statutorily exclude citizens.

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: including freedom;movement clause;another country;protections;property;a point;last entry;a citizenship;a different country;would violate many parts;the constitution<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : The US gov. could remove legal resident status from citizens.
output: This would violate many parts of the constitution including freedom of movement clause, and protections for property. Also where would you send them? They don't have a different country they can be sent to as they don't have a point of last entry or a citizenship in another country.

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: varying perspectives;a good thing;no bearing;men;equal amount;face different things;a policy writing standpoint;the fact;a different perspective;women;ones sex<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : a rise in female representation in elected government isn't a good or bad thing.
output: You are right that ones sex has no bearing on how well they will govern, but its still a good thing. The fact is, women face different things from a different perspective than men. So having a more equal amount of these varying perspectives is better from a policy writing standpoint.

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: higher representation;an issue;girls;ruling government;gender;careers;those dreams;laws;government;diversity;men;women;policy talk;bills;inspire girls;women;the stem field;views;conducted on women representation;a different pov available;suck in ruling government;studies;different point;this case<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : a rise in female representation in elected government isn't a good or bad thing.
output: Having diversity in government ( diversity being gender in this case ) allows for different point of views in policy talk and bills and laws. Women may have a different take on an issue than men. Also higher representation of women in careers leads to more girls wanting and following through on those dreams. This is seen in studies conducted on women representation and the STEM field. While men don’t suck in ruling government, women allow for a different POV available and inspire girls.

input: Generate a coherence output. Keyphrase: a good thing;a better mandate;the reason;make for more effective legislation;increases the effectivity;a rise;a separate matter;the society;effective legislation;representation;a good representation;the result;female representation;a mismatch;legislation;women;increased representation;a thing;the representation;governing bodies;the people<extra_id_98>Title: CMV : a rise in female representation in elected government isn't a good or bad thing.
output: You say that increased representation of women doesn't matter, but the reason you cite for that is that it won't make for more effective legislation. That's a mismatch, though ; representation is a thing onto itself. You could have the most " effective legislation " ( setting aside what that is, exactly ), but if the governing bodies are not a good representation of the society they legislate, the result is always going to be worse for the people than it would've been if the representation was better. In that way, a rise in female representation is a good thing onto itself, as it makes it so that legislation has a better mandate. Whether or not that increases the effectivity of said legislation is a separate matter altogether.
